title: Update regarding FinCorp
story_body:
FinCorp (FIN) is among the latest casualties in the burgeoning supply chain disruption afflicting the financial sector. Industry insiders point to a perfect storm of component shortages and logistical bottlenecks, which have culminated in a sector-wide crisis.

At the heart of the issue lies a crippling shortage of high-performance x86 processors, specifically Intel's Xeon E5-2690 v4 and Xeon E7-8890 v4 variants. These chips, boasting 14nm process nodes and 18-22 cores, are crucial for FIN's high-frequency trading platforms and risk management systems. With lead times stretching up to 52 weeks, FinCorp's procurement teams are scrambling to secure sufficient inventory.

Compounding the problem is a dearth of high-capacity, low-latency storage solutions. FIN's data warehousing and analytics infrastructure relies heavily on Samsung's 15.36TB PM1643a SSDs, which have become increasingly scarce. The resultant delays in data processing and analysis have significant implications for the company's ability to respond to market fluctuations.

Furthermore, the shortage of precision-engineered, high-reliability power supplies has forced FIN to revisit its data center design. The company's reliance on Artesyn Embedded Technologies' PS-2642, a 2640W 80 PLUS Platinum-certified power supply, has been compromised by the manufacturer's inability to meet demand. This has necessitated a costly redesign of FinCorp's data center infrastructure, with a focus on alternative, modular power architectures.

As the situation continues to unfold, FinCorp is exploring alternative sourcing arrangements and supply chain diversification strategies. However, the company's ability to maintain its competitive edge in the high-stakes world of finance will depend on its capacity to adapt to this rapidly evolving crisis.
